abstract.text: Called to validate the client certificate provided by a peer when the connection is first established.

inlineContent.text: The session that the nearby peer wishes to join.

A certificate chain, presented as an array of SecCertificateRef certificate objects. The first certificate in this chain is the peer’s certificate, which is derived from the identity that the peer provided when it called the
method. The other certificates are the (optional) additional chain certificates provided in that same array.
If the nearby peer did not provide a security identity, then this parameter’s value is
The peer ID of the sender.
Your app should call this handler with a value of
if the nearby peer should be allowed to join the session, or
otherwise.
Your app should inspect the nearby peer’s certificate, and then should decide whether to trust that certificate. Upon making that determination, your app should call the provided
block, passing either
(to trust the nearby peer) or
(to reject it).
For information about validating certificates, read

The multipeer connectivity framework makes no attempt to validate the peer-provided identity or certificates in any way. If your delegate does not implement this method, all certificates are accepted automatically.

abstract.text: A false value.
A true value.
Support peer-to-peer connectivity and the discovery of nearby devices.
An
object represents a peer in a multipeer session.
An
object enables and manages communication among all peers in a Multipeer Connectivity session.
Creates a Multipeer Connectivity session, providing security information.
The
protocol defines methods that a delegate of the
class can implement to handle session-related events. For more information, see
Indicates that the local peer finished receiving a resource from a nearby peer.
Indicates that an
object has been received from a nearby peer.
Called when a nearby peer opens a byte stream connection to the local peer.
Called to validate the client certificate provided by a peer when the connection is first established.
Indicates that the local peer began receiving a resource from a nearby peer.
Called when the state of a nearby peer changes.
A value type whose instances are either `true` or `false`.
The return type of functions that don’t explicitly specify a return type, that is, an empty tuple `()`.
